text:
Q: Cloudflare API return 403 "Enable JavaScript and cookies to continue" A:

Not related to your error, but there are several other problems with your code:

  • You are using TStringStream without specifying a TEncoding, so it will use TEncoding::Default which is ANSI on Windows and UTF-8 on other platforms. If you want to send UTF-8 encoded data, use TEncoding::UTF8 explicitly, eg:

    TStringStream * Send = new TStringStream(rtf, TEncoding::UTF8);

  • You are passing a string to TStringStream's constructor and then immediately writing a byte buffer to the same stream using its Write() method. The constructor will encode and write the string but will leave the stream's Position property at 0, so the bytes written with Write() afterwards will overwrite the string written by the constructor.

  • You are setting the TIdSSLIOHandlerSocketOpenSSL's SSLOptions->Method property to sslvSSLv23, which is not advisable. For one thing, setting sslvSSLv23 will enable SSL 2.0 and 3.0, which are not secure. But also, the SSLOptions->Method property has been deprecated for a long time. Use the SSLOptions->SSLVersions property instead, eg:

    IdSSLIOHandlerSocketOpenSSL->SSLOptions->SSLVersions = TIdSSLVersions() << sslvTLSv1 << sslvTLSv1_1 << sslvTLSv1_2;

  • "utf-8" is not a valid Content-Encoding value. If you are sending a UTF-8 encoded JSON, you should set the TIdHTTP's Request->CharSet property instead. However, the application/json media type does not require a charset attribute, and RFC 8259 requires UTF-8 when exchanging JSON between systems, so you don't actually need to specify a CharSet explicitly in this case.

  • You are setting the TIdHTTP's Request->AcceptCharSet property, but not setting its Request->Accept property. If you are expecting the response to always be JSON, then you should set the Request->Accept property to "application/json" (or whatever JSON-based media type the server actually sends).

Q: Ich erkläre React Tasklist so gut dass es selbst meine Oma verstehen würde die leider die Treppe runtergefallen ist, wie kann ich Programm verbessern A:

Most of the description isn't even a different language, it's just banging on the keyboard. The only part that even attempts to make a coherent statement is a statement about how the OP shouldn't be required to write anything at all. And the title doesn't say anything meaningful at all.

Sorry, but what you've posted is pure nonsense.

Q: How can I call one shell script from another shell script? A:

You can use /bin/sh to call or execute another script (via your actual script):

File showdate.sh

#!/bin/bash
echo "Date is: `date`"

File mainscript.sh

#!/bin/bash
echo "You are login as: `whoami`"
echo "`/bin/sh ./showdate.sh`" # Exact path for the script file

The output would be (as root):

./mainscript.sh

Output:

 You are login as: root
 Date is: Thu Oct 17 02:56:36 EDT 2013

Q: Fast sigmoid algorithm A:

My shot at this is based in y = exp(x*0.693 - 0.693) ~= 1/(1+exp(-x) for x<0 -- then flipping the curve at y_pos = 1.0f - y for the positive half plane.

Coincidentally this shifting of the argument by log(0.5) ~= 0.693 also converts the base from e to 2.

Based on the lesser known algorithms https://stackoverflow.com/a/78509807/1716339
a sufficiently fast algorithm without divisions or square roots would be

y = 638.f - min(126.0f, abs(x)); // don't allow underflow
y = std::bit_cast<float>(std::bit_cast<uint32_t>(y) << 9);
return abs_diff(x < 0 ? 0.0f : 1.0f, y); // or return x < 0 ? y : 1.0f - y;

For FP16, the magic constants would be 78.f - min(15.f), << 6.

Compared to the x/(1+abs(x)) function this approximation approaches much more rapidly to 0 and 1 -- and also produces slightly closer approximation to e.g. the swish function swish(x) = x * sigmoid(x)

  • Here red = reference x * sigmoid(x)
    blue = x * current_approx(x) ,
    yellow = x * (0.5 + 0.5*x/(1+abs(x))
